Fig. 1 Schematic illustration of the charge carrier transfer path of (a) typical heterojunction system; and (b) Z-scheme heterostructure system. Fig. 2 XRD patterns of (a) PSi; (b) g-C3N4 and g-C3N4/PSi composites with variable PSi contents (1.25, 2.50, 3.75, 5.00 wt%); (c) g-C3N4/PSi-5.00 wt% and the regional enlarge profile (inset). Fig. 3 FTIR of PSi, pure g-C3N4 and g-C3N4/PSi composites with variable PSi mass contents. Fig. 4 SEM images of (a) PSi; (b) pure g-C3N4; (c) g-C3N4/PSi-2.50 wt% samples; TEM and HRTEM images of (d and e) PSi; (f and g) pure g-C3N4; (h and i) g-C3N4/PSi-5.00 wt% samples; (j) HAADF-STEM image of g-C3N4/PSi-5.00 wt% sample and (k) the corresponding EDX elemental mapping images of C, N, O and Si elements; (l) EDX elemental analysis results of the two selected areas marked in (j). Fig. 5 (a) XPS survey spectra for pure g-C3N4 and g-C3N4/PSi-2.50 wt% composites; (b) high resolution C 1s; and (c) high resolution N 1s for pure g-C3N4 and g-C3N4/PSi-2.50 wt% composites; (d) high resolution of Si 2p for g-C3N4/PSi-2.50 wt% composites. Fig. 6 Nitrogen adsorption-desorption isotherms and the corresponding pore size distribution curves of (a) pure g-C3N4; and (b) g-C3N4/PSi-2.50 wt% composites. Fig. 7 (a) UV–Vis diffuse reflectance spectroscopy (DRS) of PSi, pure g-C3N4 and g-C3N4/PSi composites with variable PSi loading contents; and (b) Plots of the (αhv)n versus hv photon energy for PSi (n = 1/2) and g-C3N4 (n = 2). Fig. 8 (a) Photoluminescence (PL) spectra (λex = 375 nm); and (b) transient photocurrents for pure g-C3N4 and g-C3N4/PSi composites with variable PSi loading contents. Fig. 9 (a) the photocatalytic H2 evolution with 10 vol% TEOA, 3 wt% Pt, and 100 mg pure g-C3N4 and g-C3N4/PSi composite photocatalysts under visible light (≥400 nm); (b) recyclability of g-C3N4/PSi-2.50 wt% photocatalyst for the photocatalytic H2 evolution. Fig. 10 (a) UPS spectra for pure g-C3N4 and PSi; and (b) the band structure diagram of g-C3N4/PSi composites. Construction of Z-scheme heterostructure with enhanced photocatalytic H2 evolution for g-C3N4 nanosheets via loading porous silicon Yanning Shi a Jingjing Chen b Zhiyong Mao a ⁎ Bradley D. Fahlman c Dajian Wang b ⁎ a Tianjin Key Laboratory for Photoelectric Materials and Devices, School of Materials Science and Engineering, Tianjin University of Technology, Tianjin 300384, China Tianjin Key Laboratory for Photoelectric Materials and Devices School of Materials Science and Engineering Tianjin University of Technology Tianjin 300384 China b Key Laboratory of Display Materials and Photoelectric Devices, Tianjin University of Technology, Ministry of Education, Tianjin 300384, China Key Laboratory of Display Materials and Photoelectric Devices Tianjin University of Technology Ministry of Education Tianjin 300384 China c Department of Chemistry & Biochemistry and Science of Advanced Materials Program, Central Michigan University, Mount Pleasant, MI 48859, USA Department of Chemistry & Biochemistry and Science of Advanced Materials Program Central Michigan University Mount Pleasant MI 48859 USA ⁎ Corresponding authors. Graphical abstract Z-scheme heterostructure g-C3N4/PSi photocatalysts were constructed successfully by loading PSi particles on g-C3N4 nanosheets to enhance photocatalytic H2 evolution performance, resulting form improved separation rate of photogenerated charge carries associated with the construction of heterostructure at the interface. In this work, Z-scheme heterostructure were constructed over the visible light response g-C3N4 photocatalysts by loading Porous silicon (PSi) to enhance the photocatalytic H2 evolution performance. The synthesized Z-scheme g-C3N4/PSi composites with a PSi loading content of 2.50 wt% achieves the highest photocatalytic H2 evolution rate at 870.4 µmol h−1 g−1, which is about 2 times as high as the pure g-C3N4 with H2 evolution rate of 427.2 µmol h−1 g−1. Various techniques including XRD, SEM, TEM, FTIR, XPS, UPS, PL and electrochemical method were employed to demonstrate the successful construction of g-C3N4/PSi composites and to investigate the origin of the enhanced potocatalytic activity. The formed heterostructure between g-C3N4 nanosheets and PSi were verified to be the dominant reason for the enhancement of photocatalytic activity, resulting from the separation promotion of photogenerated charge carriers in a direct Z-scheme mechanism. This study presented a promising Z-scheme g-C3N4/PSi photocatalysts with promising H2 evolution performance, which might drive the progress of solar energy conversion technologies. Keywords Photocatalysts g-C3N4 Porous silicon H2 evolution Z-scheme heterostructure 1 Introduction During the past decades, there has been great interesting in developing green renewable energy, driving by the increasing awareness about the significance of energy crisis and environmental deterioration to human. Photocatalytic hydrogen evolution from water splitting employing semiconductors has emerged as a fascinating research area. The landmark event of photocatalytic water splitting into H2 using an n-type TiO2 single-crystal electrode under ultraviolet (UV) light was first reported by Honda-Fujishima in 1972 [1]. However, the large band gap (Eg ∼ 3.2 eV) of traditional TiO2-based catalysts results in a low solar energy utilization efficiency in the visible-light range, which restricts enormously its practical application [2,3]. In view of the fact that visible light contributes to about 43% of solar radiation energy, the exploitation of visible-light-response photocatalysts attracted abundant interests of researchers. Graphitic carbon nitride (g-C3N4), with a graphitic π-conjugated stacked structure consisting of tri-s-triazine repeating units, was widely reported as a fascinating visible-light-response photocatalysts combining with multiples merits of high stability, low cost and environmental benign [4–7]. g-C3N4 delivers promising photocatalytic activity for H2 evolution under visible light irradiation owing to its suitable band gap (∼2.7 eV) for the reduction of H2O, in comparison to TiO2 and other semiconductor photocatalysts [8]. Nevertheless, the pristine g-C3N4 still suffers from poor photocatalytic efficiency because of the high recombination rate of photogenerated charge carriers. Several strategies including heteroatom doping [9–11], nanostructure design [12–14], cocatalysts combination [15–17], heterojunction fabrication [18–20], etc. have been demonstrated to promote the separation efficiency of photogenerated electron-hole pairs for enhancement of photocatalytic activity. Combination of suitable noble metals (e.g. Pt, Au and Ag) cocatalysts was reported to a facile strategy to inhibit charge recombination probability, attributing to these cocatalysts served as electron traps to suppress the recombination of photogenerated charge carriers. However, the large application of noble metals cocatalysts is limited by the high cost and high rarity. Alternatively, coupling g-C3N4 with a narrower band gap semiconductor to fabricate heterojunction composites was recognized as another effective approach to enhance the photocatalytic performance, exampling as g-C3N4/BiWO6 [18], g-C3N4/ZnIn2S4 [19], g-C3N4/MoS2 [20] composites etc. The formed heterojunction between the two components could not only improve photogenerated charge separation efficiency, but also expand the light absorption region. However, the redox ability of photoexcited electrons and holes would be declined for these typical heterojunction systems, in which the photogenerated electron in the conduction band (CB) of g-C3N4 transfer into the CB of coupled semiconductor. On the contrary, the photogenerated holes of coupled semiconductor transport into the valence band (VB) of g-C3N4, as depicted in Fig. 1 (a). Similar to the typical heterojunction photocatalytic system, the Z-scheme photocatalytic heterostructures also feature above mentioned advantages [21]. For a Z-scheme heterostructure, the photogenerated electrons in the CB of the coupled semiconductor are injected into the VB and annihilate the holes of g-C3N4 (Fig. 1(b)), which suppresses the charge recombination, thereby improving the photocatalytic performance. Meanwhile, Z-scheme heterostructure photocatalysts usually show high photocatalytic activity because the strong reducibility and oxidability of the electrons on g-C3N4 and holes on the coupled semiconductor. For example, Yu et al. synthesized Z-scheme heterostructure g-C3N4/ZnO photocatalysts and investigated the photocatalytic CO2 reduction into CH3OH [22]. The g-C3N4/ZnO photocatalytic system exhibited enhanced photocatalytic activity for CO2 reduction by a factor of 2.3 compared with the pure g-C3N4. He et al. fabricated an efficient Z-scheme g-C3N4/SnO2-x photocatalysts, which delivering an Rhodamine B (RhB) degradation rate was 8.8 times higher than that of g-C3N4 [23]. Very recently, Ye et al. reported a novel Z-scheme g-C3N4/CoTiO3 photocatalytic system for H2 evolution from water splitting and demonstrated its most enhanced H2-evolution rate at 858 µmol h−1 g−1 using ethanol as a sacrificial electron donor [24]. Hence, Z-scheme heterostructure g-C3N4-based composites show great potential as an efficient photocatalyst for the photocatalytic H2 generation. However, the number of efficient g-C3N4-based Z-scheme photocatalysts is limited and the photocatalytic performances of those reported g-C3N4-based Z-scheme photocatalysts still not meets the demands of practical application. Additional efforts are necessary to exploit new g-C3N4-based Z-scheme photocatalysts with high photocatalytic efficiency. Silicon, which is abundant on the earth and low in cost, garnered considerable attentions in the fields of optoelectronics [25], solar cells [26], batteries [27], and sensors [28], etc, due to its special physical and chemical properties. In addition, Silicon can be also used as candidate for photocatalytic redox processes, in view of the efficient solar energy harvesting resulted from its extremely narrowed band gap (Eg  = 1.1 eV). Although the photocatalytic dye degradation and organic reactions for silicon photocatalysts have been well reported to be efficient in literatures [29–32], the activity of silicon in photocatalytic H2 evolution is mainly limited by the small energy difference between the band CB edges and H+/H2 reduction level [33]. Very recently, mesoporous silicon was exploited by Dai and Song et al. as an efficient photocatalyst for H2 evolution from water with no cocatalysts [34,35]. The unique mesoporous structure expands the band gaps of silicon photocatalysts and shifts the CB edge to a more negative position due to quantum confinement, which facilitates photocatalytic H2 evolution. The extended band gap and shift of band edge levels of silicon induced by nanostructure engineering provide a new choice to construct heterostructure photocatalysts coupled with g-C3N4 for high efficient photocatalytic H2 evolution. Unfortunately, to date, there is no report concerning the construction of g-C3N4/Silicon hybrid composites and its photocatalytic performance. In the present work, Z-scheme heterostructure g-C3N4/porous silicon (g-C3N4/PSi) photocatalysts were constructed by loading PSi on two-dimensional g-C3N4 nanosheets. The phase structure, chemical composition, optical property, morphology and the photocatalytic H2 evolution performance as well as the enhancement mechanism for the obtained g-C3N4/PSi composites were investigated in detail. 2 Experimental 2.1 Raw materials Mg powder, Urea and triethanolamine (TEOA) were purchased from Aladdin Industrial Corporation (Shanghai, China). Mesoporous SiO2 (MCM-41) was purchased from Tianjin Yuanli Chemical co. LTD (Tianjin, China). Deionized water was used throughout the experiments. All the raw materials used in the experiment were analytically pure and without further purification. 2.2 Preparation of porous silicon (PSi) Porous silicon (PSi) was synthesized by magnesiothermic reduction route of mesoporous SiO2 (MCM-41). Typical, mesoporous SiO2 and Mg powders with a mol ratio of 1:2 were mixed thoroughly and then transferred into an airtight stainless steel reactor to calcine at 800 °C for 10 h under an argon atmosphere in a tube furnace with heating rate of 10 °C/min. After cooling to room temperature, the obtained black powder was immersed in 0.5 M HCl solution with stirring for 6 h to remove the byproducts of MgO and Mg2Si as well as the residual Mg. Then the resulting powder was washed several times with deionized water and ethanol. Finally, the washed powder was dried in vacuum at 60 °C for 3 h. 2.3 Preparation of g-C3N4/PSi composites g-C3N4/PSi composites were fabricated via a facile polycondensation reaction of urea with above prepared PSi. In a typical process, 10 g of urea and a certain amount of PSi (0.005, 0.010, 0.015, 0.020 g, respectively) were mixed thoroughly and transferred into an alumina crucible with a cover. Then the mixture was heated in a tube furnace under an argon atmosphere at 550 °C for 3 h using a heating rate of 5 °C/min. After cooling to room temperature, the g-C3N4/PSi composites were obtained. As a comparison, pure g-C3N4 without loading PSi was prepared by the similar processes. 10 g urea could be transfer into 0.4 g g-C3N4 under the presented synthesis condition. Thus, the mass ratio of PSi in g-C3N4/PSi composites was evaluated to be about 1.25, 2.50, 3.75 and 5.00 wt% respectively. 2.4 Sample characterization The crystalline structure of the prepared samples was analyzed by an X-ray diffractometer (XRD) (Rigaku, RINT Ultima-III, Japan) with Cu-Kα radiation. The morphology and elemental analysis was measured by a scanning electron microscope (SEM) and a transmission electron microscope (TEM, JEM-6700F, Japan) equipped with energy-dispersive spectroscopy. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy and ultraviolet photoelectron spectroscopy (Thermo scientific, ESCALAB 250Xi, America) was used to characterize the chemical speciation of samples. The chemical bonding status was assessed by Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy (FTIR, Bruker, WQE-410). Ultraviolet–visible (UV–Vis) absorption spectra were measured by a UV–Visible spectrometer (TU-1901, China) with a 60-mm diameter integration sphere. Photoluminescence spectra (PL) were measured using a fluorescence spectrometer (Hitachi F-4600, Japan). Specific surface area measurements were taken using the BET method (N2 absorption, Kangta AUTOSORB-1, America). Photoelectric current (PC) response measurements was performed on an electrochemical workstation (CHI600E, China) based on a conventional three-electrode system with the as-prepared photocatalyst and PVDF (mass ratio 3:1) coated on FTO glass as a working electrode, platinum foil as a counter electrode, and saturated calomel electrode (SCE) as a reference electrode, respectively. The electrode was immersed in 1 M Na2SO4 aqueous solution, and the photocurrent was measured at a bias voltage of 0.02 V under chopped illumination with 10 s light on/off cycles. Incident light was obtained from a 300 W xenon lamp (PLS-SXE 300C, Perfectlight, Beijing). 2.5 Photocatalytic H2 evolution testing Photocatalytic hydrogen production studies were carried out in a Pyrex top-irradiation reaction vessel connected to a closed glass gas-circulation system (Lab-Solar-III, AG, Perfectlight). A 300 W xenon lamp (PLS-SXE 300C, Perfectlight) with a 400 nm cutoff filter was chosen as a visible light source, and the light intensity was 100 mW/cm2 (determined by PL-MW 2000, Perfectlight). A total of 100 mg of photocatalyst was added to an aqueous solution that contained 90 mL of water and 10 mL of triethanolamine. Then, 3 wt% of Pt nanoparticles were loaded onto the surface of the catalyst by in situ photodeposition using H2PtCl6·6H2O as the precursor. Next, the reactant solution was evacuated several times to remove air prior to the irradiation experiments. The temperature of the reaction solution was maintained at 7 °C by a flow of cooling water during the photocatalytic reaction. The evolved gases were analyzed by gas chromatography (GC 7900, Shanghai, China) equipped with a thermal conductivity detector (TCD) and a 5 Å molecular sieve column using argon as the carrier gas. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Characterizations of g-C3N4/PSi composites X-ray diffraction patterns of as-prepared PSi, pure g-C3N4 and g-C3N4/PSi composites are employed to investigate the structure, as depicted in Fig. 2 . The diffraction peaks of PSi (Fig. 2(a)) can be well indexed as the cubic phase of Si (JCPDS 27-1402) [35]. Narrow and sharp XRD peaks of PSi without noticeable amorphous scattering suggest that the PSi prepared via magnesiothermic reduction of mesoporous SiO2 have a high purity and crystallinity. Pure g-C3N4 and g-C3N4/PSi composites give two typical diffraction peaks at 2θ = 27.3° and 12.8° (Fig. 2(b)). These two peaks are attributed to a layer of conjugated aromatic ring stacking and in-plane structural packing motif of tri-s-triazine, respectively [4]. It is worth to note that the intrinsic diffraction peaks of g-C3N4 were observed clearly for g-C3N4/PSi composites, indicating these composites maintain the basic structure of g-C3N4. When the loading content of PSi increases to 5 wt%, diffraction peaks at 47.3° and 56.1° (marked by ♦) pertaining to crystalline Si were detected, as shown in Fig. 2(c), revealing the successful construction of g-C3N4/PSi composites. Owing to the low content of PSi, the diffraction peaks of Si could not be discerned in other composite samples. The structure of PSi, pure g-C3N4 and g-C3N4/PSi composites was further characterized by FTIR spectra, as shown in Fig. 3 . For the PSi, two broad absorption bands around at 3200–3600 cm−1 and 1000–1200 cm−1 are attributed to the OH group and SiOSi stretching mode respectively [29]. For pure g-C3N4 the broad absorption peak 3000–3600 cm−1 is assigned to the stretching vibrational modes of NH and OH group, respectively, which are associated with uncondensed amino groups and surface-adsorbed H2O molecules. The skeletal vibrations in the region 1200–1700 cm−1 are typical aromatic CN heterocycles of g-C3N4, and the breathing vibration at 810 cm−1 is attributed to the vibration characteristic of s-triazine ring units [5,6]. Compared to the pure g-C3N4, g-C3N4/PSi composites with different PSi loading amounts depict unchangeable FTIR absorption profiles. The results indicate that PSi loading unchanged the basic structure of g-C3N4, which is well agreeable with XRD analysis. SEM, TEM and HRTEM images as well as the STEM-EDX elemental mapping are used to investigate the morphology and composition of PSi, pure g-C3N4 and typical g-C3N4/PSi composites and the results are shown in Fig. 4 . As seen from the SEM image, the obtained PSi shows an irregular particle size with abundant porous structure (Fig. 4(a)), resulting from the reserve of porous structure of mesoporous SiO2 and the loss of O atoms from SiO2. TEM image (Fig. 4(d)) shows the obvious mesoporous existing in the obtained PSi. HRTEM image (Fig. 4(e)) reveal that PSi is composed highly interconnected crystalline Si nanoparticles. Selected-area electron diffraction (SAED) pattern (inset of Fig. 4(e)) give a concentric ring-like mode, confirming the as-prepared PSi is polycrystalline aggregation in nature. The lattice fringes extent across the nanoparticles with a d-spacing of 0.315 nm is assigned to the (1 1 1) plane, indicating the high degree of crystallinity for the obtained PSi. Layer morphology is observed from the SEM image (Fig. 4(b)) for the pure g-C3N4. TEM image (Fig. 4(f)) further confirms the nanosheets morphology of pure g-C3N4 with abundant curled edges. HRTEM image (Fig. 4(g)) of pure g-C3N4 displays a lattice interval of 0.332 nm, corresponding to the typical distance of graphite layers. The layer nanosheets structure is well illustrated for the g-C3N4/PSi composites after loading PSi (Fig. 4(c)). From the TEM image (Fig. 4(h)) of g-C3N4/PSi-5.00 wt% composites sample, it is found that PSi particles are successfully loaded on the surface of g-C3N4 nanosheets. The HRTEM image (Fig. 4(i)) of g-C3N4/PSi-5.00 wt% composites sample presents an interplanar spacing of 0.315 nm, which is in good accordance with the (1 1 1) lattice plane of PSi. To further investigate the microstructure and composition of g-C3N4/PSi composites, high-angle annular dark-field scanning transmission electron microscopy (HAADF-STEM) and EDX elemental scanning analysis were performed. As shown in Fig. 4(k), combined with the STEM image (Fig. 4(j)), the EDX mapping of elements C and N in the same region verifies the composition of g-C3N4. However, Si-K shows different shape and location, demonstrating the definite existence of PSi particles on g-C3N4 nanosheet. Furthermore, EDX elemental analysis results (Fig. 4(l)) of the selected two areas (marked in Fig. 4(j)) also give solid evidence that PSi is successfully loaded on g-C3N4 nanosheets. X-ray photoelectron spectra (XPS) are recorded to reveal the surface chemical compositions of the pure g-C3N4 and g-C3N4/PSi-2.50 wt% samples, as shown in Fig. 5 . There are three sharp peaks at 286, 398, and 530 eV in both pure g-C3N4 and g-C3N4/PSi-2.50 wt%, which are assigned to C 1s, N 1s, and O 1s signals, respectively. The observation of oxygen in the samples is mainly attributed to the adsorbed H2O on the catalyst surface [36]. In addition, the pure g-C3N4 and g-C3N4/PSi composite have similar high-resolution C 1s and N 1s spectra, as depicted in Fig. 5(b) and (c). The C 1s spectrum can be fitted by Gaussian curves with dominant components centered at 284.7 and 288.3 eV, which are respectively attributed to the signal of CC bonds of graphitic carbon impurities in g-C3N4 and sp2-hybridized carbon in the aromatic ring (NCN) [5,6]. The N 1s peak can be deconvoluted into three peaks centered at 398.8 eV, 399.6 eV and 401.1 eV, corresponding to sp2-hybridized nitrogen in Ccontaining triazine rings (CNC), bridging N atoms in N-[C]3 groups, amino groups (CNHx), respectively [5,6]. Comparing with the pure g-C3N4, a new peak positioned at 104.5 eV is observed for g-C3N4/PSi-2.50 wt% composite, which is attributed to the presence of Si atoms (Fig. 5(d)) [35]. Nitrogen adsorption/desorption measurements were carried out to investigate the specific surface area and pore size distribution of pure g-C3N4 and g-C3N4/PSi-2.50 wt% composites, as depicted in Fig. 6 . Both pure g-C3N4 and g-C3N4/PSi-2.50 wt% composites exhibit a type-Ⅳ isotherm, suggesting the presence of mesopores. The specific surface area of pure g-C3N4 and g-C3N4/PSi-2.50 wt% composites was calculated to 134.1 m2 g−1 and 133.6 m2 g−1 respectively, revealing the little impact of PSi loading on the specific surface area of g-C3N4. The pore volume of g-C3N4/PSi-2.50 wt% composite was calculated to be 1.62 cc g−1, which is larger than that of pure g-C3N4 (1.52 cc g−1). The optical properties of PSi, pure g-C3N4 and g-C3N4/PSi composites were measured by UV–Vis diffuse reflectance spectroscopy (DRS) in Fig. 7 (a). It is found that PSi shows high absorption in the entire UV–Vis light region while the pure g-C3N4 has an absorption edge at about 450 nm, corresponding to the intrinsic absorption from valence to conduction band. When PSi is loaded, the g-C3N4/PSi composites have similar absorption edges as compared to pure g-C3N4. However, a noticeable correlation between the PSi loading content and the absorption change in the region of 450–800 nm is observed. The absorption intensity increase obviously with the increase of PSi loading in visible region, due to the introduction of PSi with high absorption character in the visible light. The increasing visible light absorption indicates that g-C3N4/PSi composite photocatalysts could utilize more visible light, which is favorable for photocatalytic reaction. The band gap energy for PSi and pure g-C3N4 is evaluated to be 1.46 eV and 2.87 eV via the Tauc plot calculated from the DRS data (Fig. 7(b)). The prepared PSi shows a wider band gap than that of the bulk Si (∼1.17 eV) due to the quantum confinement induced by the porous structure. The formation of a heterostructure between the coupled two semiconductors for the composites facilitates the separation of photogenerated electron-hole paris and subsequently results in high photocatalytic performance [21]. PL measurement was demonstrate to investigate the electron transfer and separation behavior for the concerned photocatlysts. Generally speaking, a lower PL intensity indicates a high separation rate of photoexcited electron-hole pairs. Fig. 8 (a) displays the PL spectra of pure-g-C3N4 and g-C3N4/PSi composites excited by 375 nm. Obviously, the PL intensity of g-C3N4/PSi composites is lower than that of pure g-C3N4 and decreases with the increasing of PSi loading content. This phenomenon reveals the recombination rate of photogenerated charge carries is inhibited effectively by the formed heterostructre between g-C3N4 and PSi. Photocurrent experiment was performed to further approve the enhance charge separation of g-C3N4/PSi composites. Fig. 8(b) shows the transient photocurrent responses for pure g-C3N4 and g-C3N4/PSi-2.50 wt% composites under visible light irradiation in an on-and-off cycle mode. It is clearly seen than the photocurrent of g-C3N4/PSi composites is higher than that of pure g-C3N4. In addition, the photocurrent of g-C3N4/PSi composites is found to increases with the increasing of PSi loading content. These changes suggested that the separation of photogenerated charge carriers is improved by loading PSi. Both the PL and photocurrent analysis showed that the separation of photoexcited electro-hole pairs was effectively enhanced due to the formation of heterostructre at the interface between g-C3N4 and PSi, then resulting in a better photocatalytic performances. 3.2 Photocatalytic H2 evolution performance of g-C3N4/PSi composites The photocatalytic performances of the as-synthesized pure g-C3N4 and g-C3N4/PSi composites were evaluated with H2-evolution from water under visible irradiation, as shown in Fig. 9 (a). The H2 evolution rate of pure g-C3N4 is detected to be 427.2 μmol h−1 g−1, which is consistent with the previous report for g-C3N4 photocatalyst derived from urea [24]. When PSi was loaded on the surface of the g-C3N4 nanosheets, the H2 evolution rate of all the g-C3N4/PSi composites is superior to that of pure g-C3N4. Especially, the g-C3N4/-2.50 wt% composite achieves the highest photocatalytic activity with an average H2-evolution rate at 870.5 μmol h−1 g−1, which is ∼2 times higher than the pure g-C3N4. However, the H2 evolution activity decreases when the loading content of PSi is larger than the 2.50 wt%, which could possibly be ascribed to the decrease of the reaction sites resulting from overload of PSi on g-C3N4 surface. For the Si-based, especially for bare Si photocatalysts, the poor stability were declared by researchers due to the formation of a passive oxide film on the surface of Si [33,34]. In order to evaluate the stability of our presented g-C3N4/PSi photocatlysts, a recycling test on the photocatalytic H2 evolution activity was carried out (Fig. 9(b)). One can observe that the H2 evolution rate declines from 870.5 μmol h−1 g−1 to 651.7 μmol h−1 g−1 after four successive cycling H2 evolution experiments. This reveals that the photocatalytic instability should be a serious issue for g-C3N4/PSi composites in practical application. Further research is demanded to improve the stability of g-C3N4/PSi photocatalysts by optimizing the mesoporous structure, which might enable the stable phtocatalytic activity [35]. 3.3 Photocatalytic mechanism of g-C3N4/PSi composites On basis of the above experimental results, the enhancement of photocatalytic H2 evolution performance of g-C3N4/PSi composites primarily originates from the improved separation rate of photogenerated charge carries, resulting from the synergistic effect between g-C3N4 and PSi associated with the construction of heterostructure at the interface. In terms of the band gap energy of g-C3N4 (Eg  = 2.87 eV) and PSi (Eg  = 1.46 eV), there are two kinds of possible mechanisms for separation the photogenerated electron-hole pairs (Fig. 1): (a) typical heterojunction system and (b) Z-scheme heterostructure system. In order to identify the photocatalytic mechanism, band structure of g-C3N4/PSi composite is proposed by evaluating the band levels of pure g-C3N4 and PSi with Ultraviolet photoelectron spectroscopy (UPS), as shown in Fig. 10 . The VB energy (Ev ) (equivalent to ionization potential) of g-C3N4 and PSi is determined to be 6.92 and 7.42 eV by subtracting the width of the He I UPS spectra from the excitation energy (21.22 eV). The CB energy (Ec ) is thus estimated at 4.05 and 5.96 eV for g-C3N4 and PSi from formula of Ev -Eg (Eg (g-C3N4) = 2.87 eV, Eg (PSi) = 1.46 eV), respectively. The values of Ev and Ec in electron volts are converted to electrochemical energy potentials in volts according to the reference standard for which 0 versus RHE (reversible hydrogen electrode) equals −4.44 eV versus evac (vacuum level). According to these evaluated levels, the schematic energy band illustration g-C3N4/PSi with the redox potentials of the photocatalytic reaction were depicted in Fig. 10(b). If the typical heterojunction system illustrated in Fig. 1(a) is the photocatalytic reaction mechanism of g-C3N4/PSi composites, the photogenerated electrons are injected into the CB of PSi with positive potential from the CB of g-C3N4 with negative potential, then resulting in the decrease in the electron reducibility. In this case, the accumulated electrons in the CB of PSi with positive potential cannot reduce H+ into H2. Hence, the photoexcited electron-hole transfer in accordance with the typical heterojunction system will result in lower photocatalytic H2 evolution rate for g-C3N4/PSi composites. Apparently, this is conflict with the foregoing enhanced performance in photocatalytic H2 evolution. Therefore, the Z-scheme heterostructure system could be recognized to be the phtocatalytic mechanism for g-C3N4/PSi composites. In the photocatalytic system, the electrons generated from CB of PSi could transfer to the VB of g-C3N4 and the holes generated from the VB of g-C3N4 could migrate to the CB of PSi via the formed interface between g-C3N4 and PSi. These transferred electrons and holes recombine at the interface, in which large quantity of defects accumulated to serve as recombination center of electron-hole pairs [21]. As a result, the separation efficiency of photogenerated electron-hole pairs for g-C3N4 and PSi is improved, then leading to the enhancement of photocatalytic H2 evolution activity. It should be noted that the proposed schematic band structure (Fig. 10(b)) just to illustrate approximately the band alignment between the coupled two components, rather than represents the real situation when H2 evolution takes place in solution. 4 Conclusions In summary, Z-scheme heterostructures g-C3N4/PSi photocatalysts were constructed successfully by loading PSi particles on g-C3N4 nanosheets. The synthesized Z-scheme g-C3N4/PSi composites exhibit obviously enhanced photocatalytic H2 evolution activity. The g-C3N4/PSi composites with a PSi loading content of 2.50 wt% achieved the highest photocatalytic H2 evolution rate at 870.4 µmol h−1 g−1, which is ∼2 times higher than that of pure g-C3N4. The enhanced photocatalytic H2 evolution performance primarily originated from the improved separation rate of photogenerated charge carries, resulting from the synergistic effect between g-C3N4 and PSi associated with the construction of Z-scheme heterostructure at the interface. This study presented a promising Z-scheme g-C3N4/PSi photocatalysts with promising H2 evolution performance, which might drive the progress of solar energy conversion technologies. Chen A facile approach to synthesize novel oxygen-doped g-C3N4 with superior visible-light photoreactivity Chem. Commun. 48 2012 12017 12019

coredata.dc:description: In this work, Z-scheme heterostructure were constructed over the visible light response g-C3N4 photocatalysts by loading Porous silicon (PSi) to enhance the photocatalytic H2 evolution performance. The synthesized Z-scheme g-C3N4/PSi composites with a PSi loading content of 2.50 wt% achieves the highest photocatalytic H2 evolution rate at 870.4 µmol h−1 g−1, which is about 2 times as high as the pure g-C3N4 with H2 evolution rate of 427.2 µmol h−1 g−1. Various techniques including XRD, SEM, TEM, FTIR, XPS, UPS, PL and electrochemical method were employed to demonstrate the successful construction of g-C3N4/PSi composites and to investigate the origin of the enhanced potocatalytic activity. The formed heterostructure between g-C3N4 nanosheets and PSi were verified to be the dominant reason for the enhancement of photocatalytic activity, resulting from the separation promotion of photogenerated charge carriers in a direct Z-scheme mechanism. This study presented a promising Z-scheme g-C3N4/PSi photocatalysts with promising H2 evolution performance, which might drive the progress of solar energy conversion technologies.
coredata.dc:title: Construction of Z-scheme heterostructure with enhanced photocatalytic H2 evolution for g-C3N4 nanosheets via loading porous silicon
